metadata.description: Zambian Lozi (SiLozi) as spoken in Western Province/Barotseland

examples: Mu cwani - How are you
Mu cwani kakusasana - How are you this morning
mu cwani.culturalContext: Standard greeting in Lozi culture. 'Mu cwani' is formal, 'mu kaufi' is informal.

examples: Mwa Zambia kunani lifolofole zeñata - There are many animals in Zambia
Kwena ipila kuca lifolofole zeñwi zetuna - The crocodile feeds on other big animals
lifolofole.culturalContext: Refers to all types of animals, including domestic and wild.

examples: Litou lifula busihu - Elephants feed at night
Tou kiyona yetuna kakufitisisa kwa lifolofole kaufela - The elephant is the largest of all animals
Tou i buhali - The elephant is dangerous
litou.culturalContext: A significant animal in Lozi culture, often associated with strength and wisdom.
litou.usage: Commonly used to refer to elephants

examples: Linoha zaluma - Snakes bite
Noha i na ni mulelo - The snake has poison
linoha.culturalContext: Often seen as dangerous in traditional beliefs.

examples: Litau a lilati nama ya mbongolo - Lions do not like donkey meat
Tau ki mulena wa lifolofolo - The lion is the king of animals
litau.culturalContext: Symbolizes bravery in many African cultures.
litau.usage: Used in both literal and metaphorical speech

examples: Ninani musali, yomunde. - I have a good wife.
ninani.culturalContext: Used to express possession in the first person.
ninani.usage: Common for personal belongings or relationships.

examples: Unani simu yende. - He (she) has a good garden.
unani.culturalContext: Used for possession in third person singular.

examples: Lunani kaze yende. - We have a good cat.
lunani.usage: Used when referring to something owned by a group.

examples: Munani buka yende. - You have a good book.
Munani likomu zende. - You have a good herd of cattle.
Banani sikolo sesinde. - They have a good school.
Banani ndu yende. - They have a good house.
Banani mukolo womunde. - They have a good canoe.
Hanina liapalo zende. - I do not have good clothes.
hanina.culturalContext: Used to indicate the absence of possession.

examples: Haluna linja zende. - We do not have good dogs.
haluna.culturalContext: Used for negating possession in the first-person plural.
haluna.usage: Used when referring to a group.

examples: Hamuna lipho zede. - You have no good bulls.
Hamuna balikinai babande. - You have no good friends.
hamuna.culturalContext: Used to express negation in second person.

examples: Habana tunyandi totunde. - They have no good fishing nets.
habana.usage: Used when referring to absence of something in a group.

mwa Zambia kunani lifolofolo zeñata.translation: There are many animals in Zambia.
examples: Mwa Zambia kunani lifolofolo zeñata. - There are many animals in Zambia.
mwa Zambia kunani lifolofolo zeñata.culturalContext: General statement about wildlife in Zambia.

likwena lifumaneha mwa linuka nimwa masa.translation: Crocodiles are found in rivers and lakes.
likwena lifumaneha mwa linuka nimwa masa.pronunciation: lee-kweh-nah lee-foo-mah-neh-ha mwa lee-noo-kah neem-wah mah-sah
examples: Likwena lifumaneha mwa linuka nimwa masa. - Crocodiles are found in rivers and lakes.
likwena lifumaneha mwa linuka nimwa masa.culturalContext: Refers to common habitats of crocodiles.

likubu nizona lipila mwa mezi.translation: Hippos also live in the water.
examples: Likubu nizona lipila mwa mezi. - Hippos also live in the water.

kubu izwala feela hañwi ka silimo.translation: A hippo calves once a year only.
kubu izwala feela hañwi ka silimo.pronunciation: koo-boo ee-zwah-lah fee-lah ha-ñwee kah see-lee-mo
examples: Kubu izwala feela hañwi ka silimo. - A hippo calves once a year only.

kwena ipila kuca lifolofolo zeñwi zetuna.translation: The crocodile feeds on other big animals.
kwena ipila kuca lifolofolo zeñwi zetuna.pronunciation: kweh-nah ee-pee-lah koo-chah lee-fo-lo-fo-lo zen-wee ze-too-nah
examples: Kwena ipila kuca lifolofolo zeñwi zetuna. - The crocodile feeds on other big animals.
kwena ipila kuca lifolofolo zeñwi zetuna.culturalContext: Refers to the carnivorous nature of crocodiles.
kwena ipila kuca lifolofolo zeñwi zetuna.usage: Common in discussions about predator-prey relationships.

tou kiyona yetuna kakufitisisa kwa lifol.translation: The elephant is the largest of all animals.
tou kiyona yetuna kakufitisisa kwa lifol.pronunciation: too kee-yoh-nah ye-too-nah kah-koo-fee-tee-see-sah kwa lee-fo-lo-fo-lo kow-feh-lah
examples: Tou kiyona yetuna kakufitisisa kwa lifolofolo kaufela. - The elephant is the largest of all animals.
tou kiyona yetuna kakufitisisa kwa lifol.culturalContext: Describes elephants’ size relative to other animals.

examples: Litou lifula busihu. - Elephants feed at night.
litou lifula busihu.usage: Used in discussions about animal habits.

nali isabisa hahulu.translation: A buffalo is a fearful animal.
examples: Nali isabisa hahulu. - A buffalo is a fearful animal.
nali isabisa hahulu.culturalContext: Describes the aggressive nature of buffalos.

sitongwani sinani meno akolile hahulu.translation: The hyena has very strong teeth.
examples: Sitongwani sinani meno akolile hahulu. - The hyena has very strong teeth.
Linoha zaluma. - Snakes bite.
Tushakame tutaifile hahulu. - Rabbits are very clever.
tushakame tutaifile hahulu.culturalContext: Refers to common knowledge about rabbits.
tushakame tutaifile hahulu.usage: Used in comparisons or animal facts.

examples: Mawawa aluma nji? - Do jackals bite?
Kana lipombwe lisaba likulube? - Are baboons afraid of pigs?
kana lipombwe lisaba likulube?.usage: Used in informal or educational contexts.

litau a liti nama ya mbongolo.translation: Lions do not like donkey meat.
litau a liti nama ya mbongolo.pronunciation: lee-tah-oo ah lee-tee nah-mah yah mbon-go-lo
examples: Litau a liti nama ya mbongolo. - Lions do not like donkey meat.
Nimu potela nako kaufela. - I always visit him (her).
Nika mu potela kamuso. - I will visit him (her) tomorrow.
potela.culturalContext: The verb 'potela' is commonly used in Lozi to describe the act of visiting someone. It follows different conjugations depending on tense and pronoun.
potela.usage: Used when discussing visits to people.

examples: Ni kacenule nimu potezi. - I visited him (her) today.
Natilo ni potela maabani. - He (she) visited me yesterday.
potezi.culturalContext: Past tense of 'potela', used to indicate that the visit has already happened.
potezi.usage: Used when referring to past visits.

examples: Nika mu potela kamuso. - I will visit him (her) tomorrow.
Bakato ni potela kamuso. - They will visit me tomorrow.
kamuso.culturalContext: Commonly used to refer to future events.
kamuso.usage: Used when talking about the next day.

examples: Ni kacenule nimu potezi. - I visited him (her) today.
Natilo ni potela kacenu. - He (she) visited me today.
kacenu.culturalContext: Used to refer to actions happening within the same day.

examples: Neni mu potezi maabani. - I visited him (her) yesterday.
Nebatilo ni potela maabani. - They visited me yesterday.
maabani.usage: Used to talk about actions that happened the previous day.

examples: Bani potela kamita. - They always visit me.
Nebatilo ni potela kacenu. - They visited me today.
bani.culturalContext: Used when referring to a group of people.

examples: Muba potela nako kaufela. - You always visit them.
Muba potezi kacenu. - You visited them today.
muba.culturalContext: Used when addressing more than one person.

examples: Luba potela nako kaufela. - We always visit them.
Luba potezi kacenu. - We visited them today.
luba.culturalContext: Used when referring to oneself and others.

examples: Uni potela nako kaufela. - He (she) always visits me.
Ukato ni potela kamuso. - He (she) will visit me tomorrow.
Hande-nde mutu ya buza unani ngana? - Why do people ask questions?
hande-nde.culturalContext: Asking questions is encouraged in Lozi culture as a sign of intelligence.
hande-nde.usage: Used to inquire about reasons or causes.

examples: Kini, kini cwalo? - Where is it?
Kini wenda? - Where are you going?
kini.culturalContext: Often used in daily conversation to ask for locations.
kini.usage: Commonly used to ask for places or positions.

examples: Kai, kai luli? - When exactly?
Mwa bona kai? - When did you see it?
kai.culturalContext: Frequently used in both casual and formal contexts to inquire about time.
kai.usage: Used to ask about time-related matters.

examples: Mutile lili? - How did you arrive?
Lili wena upila? - How are you living?
lili.culturalContext: A fundamental question in Lozi used in different contexts.
lili.usage: Used to ask about the manner or method of an action.

examples: Cwani? - Who?
Cwani wa buza? - Who is asking?
cwani.culturalContext: A core question in Lozi, often asked in social interactions.

examples: Mani? - What is the time?
Ki nako mani? - What time is it?
mani.culturalContext: Used in both formal and informal settings to inquire about the time.
mani.usage: Asked when checking the current time.

examples: Ki nako manfi? - Where is the bathroom?
Mwani ki nako manfi? - Do you know where the bathroom is?
ki nako manfi.culturalContext: A common question when in public places.

examples: Kanti wena upila kai? - Where do you live?
Upila kai kwa mukuku? - Do you live in the village?
kanti wena upila kai.culturalContext: Often asked when getting to know someone.

examples: Mali aka akai? - Where is my money?
Nako kaza ni mali ya kwa? - When will I get my money?
mali aka akai.usage: Used when inquiring about missing money.

examples: Muya kai? - Where are you going?
Muya kwa ndandala? - Are you going to the market?
muya kai.culturalContext: Commonly asked when checking someone's destination.
muya kai.usage: Used in daily conversation to ask about movement.

examples: Kanti basizana bainzi kai? - Where are the girls?
Bainzi kwa ndandala? - Are they at the market?
kanti basizana bainzi kai.culturalContext: Commonly used in social settings when looking for someone.
kanti basizana bainzi kai.usage: Used to ask for someone's location.

hamuna litapi zede kufita ze.translation: Do you not have better fish than these?
examples: Hamuna litapi zede kufita ze? - Do you not have better fish than these?
hamuna litapi zede kufita ze.culturalContext: Fish is a staple food in Lozi culture, often discussed in markets and trade.
hamuna litapi zede kufita ze.usage: Used when negotiating or inquiring about quality.

mu lozi tota wena nji cwani.translation: You are a proper Lozi or not?
mu lozi tota wena nji cwani.pronunciation: moo lo-zee to-ta we-na nji chwa-nee
examples: Mu Lozi tota wena nji cwani? - Are you truly Lozi or not?
mu lozi tota wena nji cwani.culturalContext: Used in cultural identity discussions, questioning someone's authenticity.
mu lozi tota wena nji cwani.usage: Common in informal or cultural conversations.

examples: Mu hupalani? - What do you think?
Mu hupalani ku taba ye? - What do you think about this matter?
mu hupalani.culturalContext: Used to seek opinions in discussions.

examples: Mutokwanii? - What do you need?
Mutokwanii kwa ndandala? - What do you need from the market?
mutokwanii.culturalContext: Common in customer service and daily interactions.

examples: Kanti uezanii? - What are you doing?
Uezanii kwa lupako? - What are you doing outside?
kanti uezanii.culturalContext: A frequently asked question in daily interactions.
kanti uezanii.usage: Used to inquire about someone’s activity.

examples: Muza cwanii? - How are you?
Muza cwanii mukololo? - How are you, chief?
muza cwanii.culturalContext: A polite greeting in Lozi culture.

amu bateli kunitusa nji.translation: Don’t you want to help me?
examples: Amu bateli kunitusa nji? - Don’t you want to help me?
Mu katezi nji? - Are you tired?
mu katezi nji.culturalContext: Commonly asked after hard work or a long journey.
mu katezi nji.usage: Used in concern for someone’s well-being.

examples: Mu shwile tala nji? - Are you hungry?
Mu shwile tala ni litala? - Are you very hungry?
mu shwile tala nji.culturalContext: Food is significant in Lozi hospitality, so this is a common question.
mu shwile tala nji.usage: Used to check on someone’s hunger.

examples: Hamusika shwa linyolwa? - Are you thirsty?
Shwa linyolwa ni munandi? - Are you really thirsty?
hamusika shwa linyolwa.culturalContext: Common in hot regions where hydration is important.

examples: Ni liehii nji? - Am I late?
Ni liehii kwa kuta? - Am I late for the meeting?
ni liehii nji.culturalContext: Punctuality is valued in formal settings.
ni liehii nji.usage: Used when concerned about being on time.

examples: Kachenu ku batile - Today it is cold
Kachenu ku chisize - Today it is hot
Kufutumalile - It is warm
Kuna Lizazi - It is sunny
Kuna ni Moya - It is windy
Kachenu kwiinzi hande - Today it is better
Anihi kutwi hande - I am not well
Nini toha - I have a head ache
Mwamba muna nibutuku - My tummy hurts
Meto ani ni butuku - His eyes are sore

Franco o ya kwa sipatela.translation: Franco is going to the clinic
examples: Franco o ya kwa sipatela - Franco is going to the clinic
Franco o ya kwa sipatela.usage: Indicating someone is seeking medical help

Nayile kubona Dokota.translation: She/he went to see the doctor
examples: Nayile kubona Dokota - She/he went to see the doctor
Mauwutu aluluyile - Her leg is swollen
Uchile zezimasu - Seems he ate something bad
Uchile zezimasu.usage: Suggesting food poisoning or digestive issue

Ba bata kuya kwa sipatela.translation: They want to go to the clinic
examples: Ba bata kuya kwa sipatela - They want to go to the clinic
Ba bata kuya kwa sipatela.usage: Expressing intention to seek medical help

examples: Akuchisa - Summer
Akubata - Winter

ki mulatu wamina nji cwanii.translation: It is actually your fault, isn’t it?
examples: Ki mulatu wamina nji cwanii? - It is actually your fault, isn’t it?
Wa ziba ku zamaisa mota? - Can you drive?
wa ziba ku zamaisa mota.culturalContext: Driving is a valued skill in modern Lozi society.
wa ziba ku zamaisa mota.usage: Used to ask about driving abilities.

examples: Buka inani tuso? - Is this book useful?
Inani tuso ku bana? - Is it useful for children?
buka inani tuso.culturalContext: Education is highly valued in Lozi culture.
buka inani tuso.usage: Used in discussions about learning materials.

litumeliso hali lekwi nihaiba 1 ngwee.translation: Greetings do not cost a single ngwee.
litumeliso hali lekwi nihaiba 1 ngwee.pronunciation: lee-too-meh-lee-so ha-lee lek-wee nee-ha-ee-ba een gwee
examples: Litumeliso hali lekwi nihaiba 1 ngwee - Greetings do not cost a single ngwee.
Always greet others because litumeliso hali lekwi nihaiba 1 ngwee.
litumeliso hali lekwi nihaiba 1 ngwee.culturalContext: Emphasizes the importance of greetings and politeness in social interactions.
litumeliso hali lekwi nihaiba 1 ngwee.usage: Used to encourage people to greet one another as a sign of respect.

kumaswe he kusa lumelisa mutu yo ziba.translation: It is therefore not in order not to greet someone you know.
kumaswe he kusa lumelisa mutu yo ziba.pronunciation: koo-ma-sweh heh koo-sa loo-meh-lee-sa moo-too yo zee-ba
examples: Kumaswe he kusa lumelisa mutu yo ziba - It is therefore not in order not to greet someone you know.
In our culture, kumaswe he kusa lumelisa mutu yo ziba is an important rule.
kumaswe he kusa lumelisa mutu yo ziba.culturalContext: Highlights the importance of greeting people, especially those you recognize.
kumaswe he kusa lumelisa mutu yo ziba.usage: Used to remind others about good manners in social settings.

kana unyezi nji?.translation: By the way, are you married?
examples: Kana unyezi nji? - By the way, are you married?
Nyezwi holohatula - Yes indeed, I married two years ago.
kana unyezi nji?.culturalContext: Marriage is an important topic in social conversations.
kana unyezi nji?.usage: Used in casual conversations to inquire about someone's marital status.

examples: Unani bana? - Do you have any children?
Ni nani mwana limunwi wa musizana. - I have one daughter.
unani bana?.culturalContext: Children are highly valued in many African cultures.
unani bana?.usage: Common in conversations about family and personal life.

examples: Makuete ki afi kwanu? - What is the news?
Kuiketile, kukuzize tuuu. - Everything is all right. It is all quiet.
makuete ki afi kwanu?.culturalContext: A common greeting phrase used to check on someone's well-being.
makuete ki afi kwanu?.usage: Often used as a general greeting in conversations.

examples: Muzuhile - Good morning.
Luzuhile, muzuhile nimina. - Good morning (reply).
muzuhile.culturalContext: A polite way to greet someone in the morning.

examples: Luzuhile, muzuhile nimina - Good morning (reply).
When someone greets you 'Muzuhile', you can say 'Luzuhile, muzuhile nimina.'
luzuhile, muzuhile nimina.culturalContext: Used as a polite response when greeted in the morning.
luzuhile, muzuhile nimina.usage: Used in formal and informal greetings.

examples: Ki manzibwana - Good afternoon.
In the afternoon, you greet people by saying 'Ki manzibwana'.
ki manzibwana.culturalContext: Used as a standard afternoon greeting.

examples: Ki manzibwana nimina - Good afternoon (reply).
When greeted with 'Ki manzibwana,' respond with 'Ki manzibwana nimina.'
ki manzibwana nimina.culturalContext: Used as a polite response to an afternoon greeting.

examples: Mukutule - Welcome back.
After a long journey, people will greet you with 'Mukutule'.
mukutule.culturalContext: A friendly way to welcome someone back.
mukutule.usage: Used when someone returns home or to a familiar place.

examples: Mu ilo feza musebezi? - Have you finished the work?
Yes, ninifeleze musebezi waka - Yes, I have completed the piece of work I was doing.
mu ilo feza musebezi?.culturalContext: Work and productivity are valued aspects of life.
mu ilo feza musebezi?.usage: Common in workplaces and daily life discussions.

examples: Mu siyale foo - Goodbye (person leaving).
When someone is leaving, say 'Mu siyale foo' to bid them farewell.
Sopa ki kweli ya pili - January is the first month
Lu ka kopana ka kweli ya Yowa - We will meet in the month of February
Ni pepilwe ka Liatamanyi - I was born in March
Lungu ki kweli ya bune - April is the fourth month
Mutokwa wa hae u ka kala mwa Kandao - Her wedding will be in May
Mbuwana ki kweli ya silela - June is the sixth month
Ba ya kwa sikolo ka Sikulu - They go to school in July
Ku bata hahulu ka Muyana - It is very cold in August
Likoto li ka tomwa ka Muimunene - The fields will be prepared in September
Pula i ka nela ka Yenda - It will rain in October
Lu ka kuta kwa hae ka Njimwana - We will return home in November
Lisunda za Kresmasi li ka mwa Ng'ulule - Christmas holidays are in December
Kubu i pila mwa nuka - The hippopotamus lives in the river

Folofolo.culturalContext: General term for hoofed wild animals

examples: Kaze i swala limbeba - The cat catches mice
Komu i fa mabisi - The cow gives milk
Longolo i cinca mibala - The chameleon changes colors
Mukolozwani u zamaya fa limota - The lizard walks on walls
Nja ya ka i lata ku bapala - My dog likes to play
Pofu i tiile - The eland is strong
Liuyi li luka kamba - The spider weaves a web
Tutwa i na ni mulala o mutelele - The giraffe has a long neck
Mbi i na ni mipende - The zebra has stripes
Chikwe i fufa fa nuka - The spur-winged goose flies over the river
Imuyulu i pila fa mezi - The knob-nose duck lives on water
Kachonkavole i opela hande - The bulbul sings well
Kamonge ki folofolo yenyinyani - The blue duiker is a small animal
Lingwalala li na ni mibala ye minsu ni ye misweu - The pied crow has black and white colors
Lisikita li bona hande busihu - The eagle owl sees well at night
Maiva ki sisupo sa kozo - The dove is a symbol of peace
Mankoli i lata ku zuma linyunywani - The yellow-billed kite likes to hunt birds
Nalukapwa i na ni milala yetelele - The purple heron has a long neck
Nalulenge i na ni mahutu atelele - The black-winged stilt-bird has long legs
Nalumbe i zamaya fa matali a mezi - The African jacana walks on water lilies
Nasikambo i na ni mulomo o mutelele - The sacred ibis has a long beak
Ngwanye i zuma litapi - The fish eagle hunts fish
Nongolo i na ni mulomo o sikamuhile - The open-billed stork has a gapped bill
Sipato si fufa fa mezi - The duck flies over water
Tivakolo i na ni mibala ye minde - The barbet has many colors
Mutozi chwani, mulena - Good morning/day/evening, chief
Mutozi chwani.culturalContext: Formal greeting, literally means 'how have you risen?'

examples: Kibusiwu, muyaha - Good morning/day/evening, friend
Kibusiwu ima, ku cwani? - Good day madam, how are you?
Nitu se - Help me
Nibata unitu se - I need help
Nebaninetile - I have been attacked
Bani nata - I am being attacked

Ba uzwize mwandu yaka.translation: My house has been broken into
examples: Ba uzwize mwandu yaka - My house has been broken into

Ba uzwiza mwandu.translation: There has been theft in my house
examples: Ba uzwiza mwandu - There has been theft in my house
Bani amuyi lika - I have been robbed
Taha Kwanu - Come here
Mutozi chwani, mulatiwa? - How are you, dear?
Na nami siya - Good-bye
Nimi siyile - See you
Mutola hande - Have a good day
Mutola hande.usage: Wishing someone a good day when parting

examples: Mulobale hande - Good night
Ulobale hande - Good night
Kakubona kamuso - See you tomorrow
Kakubona kamuso.usage: Parting with specific next meeting time

examples: Kakubona ape - See you later
Kakubona ape.usage: Indicating future meeting without specific time

examples: Ni tozi hande, ni itumezi - I am fine, thank you
Mulumele Basali ni Bana, ni tabile ku mi bona - Good day ladies and gentlemen, I am happy to see you
Enisha Mulumela, batu! - How are you, people!
Lu wiinzi hande, lu itumezi - We are well, thank you
Ulumele, kambe lu ka kopana - Good day, we will meet again
Ulumele/Mulumele.culturalContext: Mulumela is not specific to any time of day. Men are expected to take off their hats/caps when greeting elders.

examples: Ni nzi Hande, ni itumezi - I am well, thank you
Luitumezi ka tuso ya hao - Thank you for your help
Mulumela Ndate, u zamaya cwani? - Good day sir, how are you doing?
Mulumela Ima, u zamaya cwani? - Good day madam, how are you doing?
Go - To
Go.usage: Prefix indicating infinitive form of verbs

examples: Kona - Able
kuhupulitsa - remind
Nisabile - Afraid of
Alaba - Answer
Utile - Arrive
Kupa - Ask
Na Kupa - Ask for (polite way)
Uza maile - Away, go; travel
Ubile - Be, become
Kala ku - Begin
Nalumela - Believe, agree
Bilisa - Boil
Nakupa nika kufa - Borrow
Tisa Kwanu - Bring
Tisa Kwanu.usage: Requesting someone to carry something to speaker

examples: Chisa - Burn
Pumbeka - Bury
Leka - Buy
Biza Mutu usili - Call another person
Nanula - Carry
Pahama - Climb
Kwala - Close
Taha - Come
Kena - Come in
Zwa - Come out (emerge)
Apeha - Cook

Bina - Dance
Kuliyeya - Delay
Sinya - Destroy
Yeza - Do
Nwa - Drink
phakela - Early
phakela.usage: Indicating something happening sooner than expected

examples: Cha - Eat
Kena - Enter
Inga - Take it
Utwa - Feel; Hear; Taste
Felize - Finish
Fumana - Find
Fix, prepare - Fix, prepare
Swalela - Forgive

Wapila - Live

Kwalula - Open
Fita - Pass
Lifa - Pay

Beya - Place

Bulela - Say
Lekisa - Sell
Kula - Sick
Ina fafasi - Sit down
Lobala - Sleep
Hoha - Smoke
Bulela - Speak
Lobala - Spend the night
Siyala - Stay behind
Inga - Take
Luta - Teach
Bulela - Tell
Mabote - Tired, become
Lika - Try
Kuwutwa - Understand

Mata - Ran

Tapa - bathe
